etymology.description: 牵牛(‘morning glory’; lit. lead an ox) + 花(‘flower’) = morning glory flower.
etymology.interpretation: Commonly names the vine whose trumpet-like blossoms open in the morning; 牵牛 is an established plant morpheme from the classical herb term 牵牛子, and 花 marks it as the flower.
etymology.simplification: 牽 was simplified to 牵 by reducing components to fewer strokes; 牛 and 花 are unchanged.

parts.english: to pull; to lead; to involve; to drag

examples.chinese: 篱笆上爬满了牵牛花(籬笆上爬滿了牽牛花)。
examples.pinyin: Líbā shàng pá mǎn le qiānniúhuā.
examples.english: Morning glories climbed all over the fence.

examples.chinese: 牵牛花清晨开放(牽牛花清晨開放)，午后便合拢(午後便合攏)。
examples.pinyin: Qiānniúhuā qīngchén kāifàng, wǔhòu biàn hélǒng.
examples.english: Morning glories open at dawn and close by afternoon.

examples.chinese: 她把几颗牵牛花种子撒在花盆里(她把幾顆牽牛花種子撒在花盆裡)。
examples.pinyin: Tā bǎ jǐ kē qiānniúhuā zhǒngzǐ sǎ zài huāpén lǐ.
examples.english: She scattered a few morning glory seeds in the flowerpot.
